greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Absolute difference between sum of odd divisors of n and sum of even divisors of n.
comment: The generating function equals 1/8 at q = Lambda = 0.1076539192... (A072558) the "One-Ninth" constant. - _Michael Somos_, Jul 21 2006
Absolute value of A002129. - _John W. Layman_, Sep 27 2012
reference: G. H. Hardy, Ramanujan: twelve lectures on subjects suggested by his life and work, AMS Chelsea Publishing, Providence, Rhode Island, 2002, p. 142.
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, One-Ninth Constant
formula: Multiplicative with a(2^e) = 2^(e+1)-3 if e>0, a(p^e) = (p^(e+1)-1)/(p-1) if p>2.
Expansion of (1-(2/Pi)^2(2E(k)-K(k))K(k))/8 in powers of nome q where E(k) and K(k) are complete elliptic integrals and q=exp(-Pi*K(k')/K(k)). - _Michael Somos_, Jul 21 2006
Bisection: a(2*k-1) = A000203(2*k-1), a(2*k) = A146076(2*k) - A000593(2*k), k >= 1. See the Hardy reference where a(n) = sigma^*_1(n). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Jan 07 2017

Define a(n) = 0 for n < 1. Then a(n) = e(n) + a(n-1) + a(n-3) - a(n-6) - a(n-10) + + - -, where [1, 3, 6, 10, ...] is the sequence of triangular numbers A000217, and e(n) = (-1)^(n+1)*n if n is a triangular number; otherwise e(n) = 0. Examples of this recurrence are given below. (End)
Dirichlet g.f.: Sum_{n>0} a(n)/n^s = zeta(s) * zeta(s-1) * (1+2^(3-3*s)) / (1+2^(1-s)). - _Werner Schulte_, Jan 23 2021
example: n = 16: n is a not triangular number, so e(n) = 0 and a(16) = a(15) + a(13) - a(10) - a(6) + a(1) =  24 + 14 - 6 - 4 + 1 = 29. (End)
mathematica: max = 80; s = (1/x)*Sum[k*x^k/(1 - (-x)^k), {k, 1, max}] + O[x]^max; CoefficientList[s, x] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Dec 04 2015 *)
program: (PARI) {a(n)=local(A,p,e); if(n<1, 0, A=factor(n); prod(k=1,matsize(A)[1], if(p=A[k,1], e=A[k,2]; if(p==2, 2^(e+1)-3, (p^(e+1)-1)/(p-1)))))}
results.author: _Michael Somos_, Oct 17 2005
